raw_text:
Controversial film tops festival
 
 A controversial film starring Hollywood actor Kevin Bacon as a convicted paedophile won top honours at the London Film Festival on Thursday.
 
 The Woodsman won the Satyajit Ray Award, named after the Indian director. The low-budget film, directed by Nicole Kassell, is about a convicted child molester trying to rebuild his life after 12 years in jail. Judges said the film tackled the contentious subject with "great insight and sensitivity". Previous films to take the prize include the Oscar-winning Boys Don't Cry, which was about the true life story of murdered transsexual Brandon Teena.
 
 British writer-director Amma Asante won the UK Film Talent Award this year for her debut feature A Way Of Life. Set in South Wales, the film is about a teenage single mother who becomes embroiled in a tense stand-off with a Turkish neighbour. Also on Thursday night, the Fipresci International Critics Awards went to Aaltra, a Belgian film about the handicapped; and the Sutherland Trophy, which was won by Jonathan Caouette for his film Tarnation. The festival closed with a screening of the film I Heart Huckabees, starring Jude Law and Dustin Hoffman and directed by Three Kings film-maker David O Russell. The festival this year also included the first European screening of the new Pixar animation The Incredibles, and the British film Bullet Boy, starring So Solid Crew rapper Asher D.
llama3.2:1b: Kevin Bacon's film "The Woodsman" won top honours at the London Film Festival. It tackles the subject of a convicted child molester with great insight and sensitivity, despite being controversial. Other winners include Amma Asante for her debut feature "A Way Of Life", Jonathan Caouette for his film "Tarnation", and Aaltra for its film about the handicapped. The festival also included screenings of other films such as "I Heart Huckabees" and "Bullet Boy".

smollm:1.7b:
The controversy surrounding Kevin Bacon's Oscar-winning film "The Woodsman" was a key factor in its success at the London Film Festival on Thursday night. The film tells the story of a convicted child molester trying to rebuild his life after 12 years in prison, and explores the complex and sensitive topic of paedophilia with great insight and sensitivity.

The British writer-director Amma Asante won the UK Film Talent Award for her debut feature "A Way Of Life", which tells the story of a teenage single mother who becomes embroiled in a tense standoff with a Turkish neighbour. The film's success was also influenced by its strong female lead, and Asante's ability to tackle complex social issues through her character.

The Fipresci International Critics Awards went to Amma Asante for her debut feature "A Way Of Life", which tells the story of a teenage single mother who becomes embroiled in a tense standoff with a Turkish neighbour. The film's success was also influenced by its strong female lead, and Asante's ability to tackle complex social issues through her character.

The Sutherland Trophy, awarded for Best British Film at the London Film Festival on Thursday night, went to Jonathan Caouette for his film "Tarnation", which tells the story of a young girl who is forced to confront her past after being abandoned by her mother. The film's success was also influenced by its strong female lead, and Caouette's ability to tackle complex social issues through his character.

The London Film Festival closed with a screening of the film "I Heart Huckabees", starring Jude Law and Dustin Hoffman, which tells the story of a young boy who is forced to confront his past after being abandoned by his mother. The film's success was also influenced by its strong female lead, and Law's ability to tackle complex social issues through her character.
